title: Pulmonary Embolism Severity Index (PESI)
description: Predicts 30-day outcome of patients with pulmonary embolism using 11 clinical criteria. This validated prognostic tool stratifies mortality risk into five severity classes to guide treatment decisions and disposition planning, particularly identifying low-risk patients suitable for outpatient management.

parameters.name: age
parameters.description: Patient age in years (contributes absolute value as points)

parameters.name: cancer_history
parameters.description: History of cancer (active cancer or cancer treatment within 6 months)

parameters.name: chronic_lung_disease_history
parameters.description: History of chronic lung disease (COPD, interstitial lung disease, etc.)

parameters.name: heart_rate_110_or_higher
parameters.description: Heart rate 110 beats per minute or higher

parameters.name: systolic_bp_less_than_100
parameters.description: Systolic blood pressure less than 100 mmHg

parameters.name: respiratory_rate_30_or_higher
parameters.description: Respiratory rate 30 breaths per minute or higher

parameters.name: altered_mental_status
parameters.description: Altered mental status (confusion, disorientation, somnolence, coma)

parameters.name: oxygen_saturation_less_than_90
parameters.description: Oxygen saturation less than 90% on room air

result.name: pesi_score
result.description: PESI score determining pulmonary embolism severity and mortality risk class

ranges.interpretation: Very low risk for mortality (0.0-1.6%). Patient may be suitable for outpatient treatment with proper anticoagulation and close follow-up. Consider discharge with oral anticoagulation if no other contraindications.
Low risk for mortality (1.7-3.5%). Patient may be suitable for outpatient treatment or brief observation. Consider discharge with appropriate anticoagulation therapy and close outpatient follow-up.
Intermediate risk for mortality (3.2-7.1%). Consider inpatient management with standard monitoring and anticoagulation therapy. Requires careful evaluation for outpatient management eligibility.

High risk for mortality (4.0-11.4%). Requires inpatient management with close monitoring and aggressive anticoagulation. Consider advanced therapies if clinically appropriate and monitor for complications.

Very high risk for mortality (10.0-24.5%). Requires immediate inpatient management with intensive monitoring. Consider ICU care, advanced therapies (thrombolysis, embolectomy), and aggressive supportive measures.

references: Aujesky D, Obrosky DS, Stone RA, Auble TE, Perrier A, Cornuz J, et al. Derivation and validation of a prognostic model for pulmonary embolism. Am J Respir Crit Care Med. 2005;172(8):1041-6. doi: 10.1164/rccm.200506-862OC.

Aujesky D, Roy PM, Verschuren F, Righini M, Osterwalder J, Egloff M, et al. Outpatient versus inpatient treatment for patients with acute pulmonary embolism: an international, open-label, randomised, non-inferiority trial. Lancet. 2011;378(9785):41-8. doi: 10.1016/S0140-6736(11)60824-6.

Jiménez D, Aujesky D, Moores L, Gómez V, Lobo JL, Uresandi F, et al. Simplification of the pulmonary embolism severity index for prognostication in patients with acute symptomatic pulmonary embolism. Arch Intern Med. 2010;170(15):1383-9. doi: 10.1001/archinternmed.2010.199.

Kearon C, Akl EA, Ornelas J, Blaivas A, Jimenez D, Bounameaux H, et al. Antithrombotic Therapy for VTE Disease: CHEST Guideline and Expert Panel Report. Chest. 2016;149(2):315-352. doi: 10.1016/j.chest.2015.11.026.
formula: PESI Score = Age + 10×(if male) + 30×(if cancer) + 10×(if heart failure) + 10×(if chronic lung disease) + 20×(if HR≥110) + 30×(if SBP<100) + 20×(if RR≥30) + 20×(if temp<36°C) + 60×(if altered mental status) + 20×(if O2 sat<90%)
notes: Extensively validated prognostic tool with strong evidence base
Age contributes absolute value as points (e.g., 65-year-old gets 65 points for age)
Male sex adds 10 points due to higher mortality risk
Classes I and II (≤85 points) may be candidates for outpatient management
Clinical judgment should always supplement PESI score
Does not replace clinical assessment for other contraindications to outpatient treatment
Simplified PESI (sPESI) is also available with 6 criteria instead of 11
Strong evidence supports use for identifying patients appropriate for outpatient management
Area under ROC curve (c-index) of 0.78 in derivation study
Validated in over 15,000 patients across multiple studies
Recommended by multiple clinical guidelines for PE risk stratification
Should be used in conjunction with bleeding risk assessment
Does not predict recurrence risk or guide duration of anticoagulation
Consider social factors and support systems when making disposition decisions
Re-evaluate if clinical condition changes significantly during treatment
